review.title: Inferring Networked Device Categories from Low-Level Activity Indicators
review.abstract: We study the problem of inferring the type of a networked device in a home network by leveraging low level traffic activity indicators seen at commodity home gateways. We analyze a dataset of detailed device network activity obtained from 240 subscriber homes of a large European ISP and extract a number of traffic and spatial fingerprints for individual devices. We develop a two level taxonomy to describe devices onto which we map individual devices using a number of heuristics. We leverage the heuristically derived labels to train classifiers that distinguish device classes based on the traffic and spatial fingerprints of a device. Our results show an accuracy level up to 91% for the coarse level category and up to 84% for the fine grained category. By incorporating information from other sources (e.g., MAC OUI), we are able to further improve accuracy to above 97% and 92%, respectively. Finally, we also extract a set of simple and human-readable rules that concisely capture the behaviour of these distinct device categories.

sections.heading: 3. DATASET
sections.text: The 240 households included in our dataset were subscribers to a (single) major European ISP during the specified period and were recruited for a test deployment. Home gateways in these households were identical to all other subscribers, except for one aspect: in-use gateways routinely queried a number of software counters and state variables on the gateway and reported them to a back-end server. Home gateways, spanning four different hardware models, were designed for triple-play service (voice, broadband, IPTV) and had 4 physical Ethernet ports and an 802.11b / g / n 2x2 WiFi access point. Importantly, the WiFi access point was available throughout the test period and during the entire test operation.

sections.heading: 7. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: In this paper, we described a methodology for identifying the category of a connected device based on low indicators of network activity on home Internet gateways. We analyzed in detail a dataset of 240 participant homes and extracted a set of characteristics that concisely capture the behavior of the devices in our dataset (which were then extensively checked by manual inspections), and then experimented with a number of well-known classification methods to predict the labels we had previously received. Overall, we found that the coarse-grained marking of a class can be derived with very high accuracy.
